ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to analyze films and literature on a deeper level. I learned to not take what the narrator says at face value, and how to identify the motivations and biases of characters. Moreover, I learned about Greek culture through Greek works of art.
I gained valuable insight into the transition from antiquity to modernity in Greece over the past century. I also improved my writing through the weekly discussion posts.

I learned a lot about how to analyze patterns within films and novels. The class also taught me to think more in depth when it comes to identifying important societal themes and topics embedded within the Greek films and novels such as what family dynamics within Greek culture represent.
Improved analytical skills for literature and writing, knowledge of Greek history and family dynamics,

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course was amazing, a five minute break midway through the class would have been nice to stretch my legs and rest for a moment, but in terms of material and teaching style the course was amazing. 

The material and the way in which we discussed it was incredible, I feel I grew as a reader and viewer of films through class discussions.

The strengths are the in depth discussions we had and how organically the discussions flowed. Professor fosters an environment where people are encouraged to contribute and share their opinion. At times, it seemed that a more clear structure of the course would have been more helpful, however, this allowed for more flexibility in a sense.
The strengths of this course is that the stories we cover are very interesting. An improvement that could be made to the course is that it the time could be cut down a little.

Strengths: fascinating discussions and usually fascinating (if very strange) texts, a lot of points of analysis are quite relevant for everyone not just Greeks. I liked the weekly short writing assignment format
Weaknesses: The only time we actually wrote a long formal essay was the very end, which felt a little new because we hadnt done it before (perhaps by design)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I loved the course. Class discussions are genuinely interesting and engaging, and Professor is more than willing to take the time out of his day to discuss course material, engage with his students as human beings, and help students improve their writing. Lastly, the literature and films we looked at in the course were very interesting and intellectual stimulating.

Yes, absolutely. It's a small class which allows for close connection and togetherness while learning about some really interesting topics through a diverse selection of literature and films. The once-a-week schedule while being almost 2 hours allows for genuine and detailed discussion among students and the professor.
Absolutely!! This class was unique from all the ones I took this semester and it was fun, engaging, and definitely worthwhile!

Yes, the discussions alone make the class worth it but only if youre willing to commit to the oddness of the texts. I feel like if you are constantly refusing to take the texts for what they are because youre disturbed by them you will not get much out of the class.

extras.title: FILM 243 01/MGRK 218 01/WGSS 245 01 - Family in Greek Lit & Film TR
